quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: ... our goal with Cursor is to invent a new type of programming, a very different way to build software. So a world kind of after code, I think that more and more being an engineer will start to feel like being a logic designer, and really, it will be about specifying your intent for how exactly you want everything to work.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A clear mental model for “after code”: engineers shift from writing code to specifying intent and logic, guiding product and workflow decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We definitely didn't expect to be doing any of our own model development. And at this point, every magic moment in Cursor involves a custom model in some way.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Counterintuitive product lesson: differentiated UX “magic moments” may require custom model work, not just integrating frontier APIs.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Many people you hear hire too fast, I think we actually hired too slow to begin with.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Contrarian hiring takeaway that challenges the default “don’t hire too fast” advice and suggests under-hiring can be a bigger early risk.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The growth has been fairly just consistent on an exponential. And exponential to begin with feels fairly slow when the numbers are really low, and it didn't really show off to the races to begin with.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A useful growth lens: early exponential growth can look unimpressive, so teams should evaluate trajectory rather than raw early numbers.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You guys went from $0 to 100 million ARR in a year and a half, which is historic.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark that frames the scale and speed of Cursor’s adoption and can calibrate expectations for breakout growth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth, and for understanding the performance of new features, and Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity, while unlocking rigorous deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights experimentation as a core growth lever and emphasizes pairing speed with rigor in analysis.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most was our experimentation platform, where I could set up experiments easily, troubleshoot issues, and analyze performance all on my own.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concrete example of self-serve experimentation enabling faster iteration without heavy dependencies on other teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more, with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time, an accessible UI for diving deeper into performance, and out-of-the-box reporting that helps you avoid annoying, prolonged analytics cycles.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on what to look for in experimentation tooling: faster stats, deeper analysis UX, and automated reporting to reduce cycle time.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta's market-leading trust management platform helps you continuously monitor compliance, alongside reporting and tracking risk.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Frames compliance as an ongoing monitoring system paired with risk tracking, not a one-time checklist exercise.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus, you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A specific, practical time-saver for teams dealing with repetitive security review workflows.

quotes.topic_title: What comes after code
quotes.text: Our goal with Cursor is to invent sort of a new type of programming, a very different way to build software, that's kind of just distilled down into you describing the intent to the computer for what you want in the most concise way possible, and really distilled down to just defining how you think the software should work, and how you think it should look.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A clear framework for “post-code” development: optimize for expressing intent (behavior + UI) as concisely as possible.

quotes.topic_title: What comes after code
quotes.text: And we think that there are problems with both of those visions. I think that on the chatbot style end of things... And we think it's going to look weirder than both.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A contrarian stance that rejects both “nothing changes” and “just chat with a bot,” implying a third interface paradigm practitioners should anticipate.

quotes.topic_title: What comes after code
quotes.text: The problem with the chatbot style end of things is that lacks a lot of precision. If you want humans to have complete control over what the software looks like, and how it works, you need to let them gesture at what they want to be changed in a form factor that's more precise than just, "Change this about my app." In a text box, removed from the whole thing.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Actionable product/design principle: high-leverage AI tooling must support precise, in-context edits rather than detached chat requests.

quotes.topic_title: What comes after code
quotes.text: And so a world after code, I think that it looks like a world where you have a representation of the logic of your software that does look more like English, you have written down... You can imagine in kind of an evolution of programming language towards pseudocode.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A concrete mental model for the next abstraction layer: “logic as English-like pseudocode” that remains editable and inspectable.

quotes.topic_title: What comes after code
quotes.text: Yep. We think it ends up looking like that, and we're very opinionated that that path goes through existing professional engineers, and it looks like this evolution away from code. And it definitely looks like the human still being in the driver's seat, and the human having both a ton of control over all aspects of the software and not giving that up.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A strategic takeaway for practitioners: the transition is engineer-led and centered on preserving human control, not replacing it.

quotes.topic_title: Skills that matter: taste and logic design
quotes.text: And so I think that more and more, being an engineer will start to feel like being a logic designer, and really, it will be about specifying your intent for how exactly you want everything to work. It'd be more about the whats, and a little bit less about how exactly you're going to do things under the hood.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A practical reframing of engineering as intent specification and high-level logic design rather than low-level implementation.

quotes.topic_title: Skills that matter: taste and logic design
quotes.text: But I think we will get to a place where you'll be able to be less careful as a software engineer, which, right now, is an incredibly, incredibly important skill. We'll move a little bit from carefulness, and a little bit more towards taste.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prediction that meticulousness will matter less over time as AI improves, shifting advantage toward judgment and taste.

quotes.topic_title: Skills that matter: taste and logic design
quotes.text: That is a state of creation that then has lots of problems, you don't really... By not understanding the details under the hood right now, you then very quickly get to a place where you're kind of limited at a certain point, where you create something that's big enough that you can't change.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A cautionary, actionable warning about the maintainability ceiling you hit when generating code without understanding it.

quotes.topic_title: Skills that matter: taste and logic design
quotes.text: I'm thinking having the right idea for what should be built.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A crisp definition of “taste” as product judgment—choosing the right thing to build—rather than purely aesthetic sensibility.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: from mechanical engineering to Cursor
quotes.text: Cursor kind of started as a solution search of a problem, and a little bit where it very much came from reflecting on how AI was going to get better over the course of the next 10 years.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A product-founding approach: start from a clear view of where the underlying technology is heading, then search for the right problem to solve.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: from mechanical engineering to Cursor
quotes.text: Another moment that got us really excited was the series of scaling on papers coming out of OpenAI and other places that showed that even if we had no new ideas, AI was going to get better and better just by pulling on simple levers, like scaling up the models, and also scaling up the data that was going into the models.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A concrete lens for AI product bets: if capability will rise via predictable “simple levers,” it can justify building ahead of the curve.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: from mechanical engineering to Cursor
quotes.text: And that set us on the path to an idea generation exercise, it was like, "How are these areas of knowledge work going to change in the future as this tech gets more mature? What is the end state of the work going to look like? How are the tools that we use to do that work going to change? How are the models going to need to get better to support changes in the work? And once scaling and pre-training ran out, how are you going to keep pushing for technological capabilities?"
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology for choosing what to build: envision the end-state workflow, tool changes, model requirements, and post-scaling capability strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: from mechanical engineering to Cursor
quotes.text: And the misstep at the beginning of Cursor is we actually worked on... We sort of did this whole grand exercise, and we decided to work on an area of knowledge work that we thought would be relatively uncompetitive, and sleepy, and boring, and no one would be looking at it, because we thought, "Oh, coding's great, coding's totally going to change with this AI, but people are already doing that."
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A contrarian lesson against “avoid crowded markets”: picking a sleepy space can be a trap if it pulls you away from where the biggest transformation is happening.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: from mechanical engineering to Cursor
quotes.text: There were problems around, how would you actually take the models that exist to today and make them useful for mechanical engineering? The way we netted out is, you need to actually develop your own models from the get-go.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A practical product constraint: some domains won’t work with off-the-shelf models, forcing an early decision about whether you can (or should) build domain-specific models.

quotes.topic_title: Why build an IDE, not just agents or models
quotes.text: we care about giving humans control over all of the decisions in the end tool that they're building.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A clear product principle: design AI dev tools to keep humans as the ultimate decision-makers rather than fully autonomous systems.

quotes.topic_title: Why build an IDE, not just agents or models
quotes.text: we've tried to be intense realists about where the technology is today, very, very, very excited about how AI is going to mature over the course of many decades.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A practical mindset for builders: balance long-term optimism with near-term realism when choosing product bets and UX constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Why build an IDE, not just agents or models
quotes.text: There's an instinct to see AI do magical things in one area, and then kind of anthropomorphize these models, and think it's better than a smart person here, and so it must be better than a smart person there.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A contrarian warning against overgeneralizing model capability from impressive demos to broader, decision-heavy workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Why build an IDE, not just agents or models
quotes.text: From the very start, our product development process was really about dogfooding, and using the tool intensely every day.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: An actionable methodology: use heavy internal usage to pressure-test what actually works before shipping AI features.

quotes.topic_title: Why build an IDE, not just agents or models
quotes.text: the extensibility that existing coding environments have is so, so, so limited, so if you think that the UIs may change a lot, if you think that the form factor programming is going to change a lot, necessarily need to have control over the entire application.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A strategic product rationale: if you expect major workflow/UI shifts, owning the full IDE can be necessary versus relying on plugins.

quotes.topic_title: Foreground vs background agents and task fit
quotes.text: I think you'll want the ability to move between all of these things fairly effortlessly, and sometimes I think you will want to have the thing kind of go spin off on its own for a while, and then I think you'll want the ability to pull in the AI's work, and then work with it very, very, very quickly, and then maybe have it go spin off again.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A practical workflow model: alternate between background execution and tight, fast foreground iteration to maintain speed and control.

quotes.topic_title: Foreground vs background agents and task fit
quotes.text: And so these kind of background versus foreground form factors, I think you want that all to work well in one place.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Guidance for tool design and team setup: don’t pick one agent mode—integrate both into a single cohesive environment.

quotes.topic_title: Foreground vs background agents and task fit
quotes.text: And I think the background stuff, there's a segment of programming that it's especially useful for, which is type of programming tasks where it's very easy to specify exactly what you want without much description, and exactly what correctness looks like without much description.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A task-fit heuristic for when to use background agents: prefer tasks with crisp specs and unambiguous correctness criteria.

quotes.topic_title: Foreground vs background agents and task fit
quotes.text: Bug fixes are a great example of that, but it's definitely not all of programming.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A concrete example plus a boundary condition: background agents shine on bug fixes, but practitioners shouldn’t overgeneralize to all work.

quotes.topic_title: Foreground vs background agents and task fit
quotes.text: Or you can really chop things up. So you can specify a little bit, AI writes something, review, specify a little bit, AI writes something, review.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: An actionable methodology for reducing review pain: break work into small spec→generate→review loops instead of big handoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Early build and launch: hand-rolled editor to VS Code
quotes.text: So when we started building Cursor, we were fairly paranoid about spinning for a while, without releasing to the world.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A practical launch mindset: avoid overbuilding in private and create pressure to ship early.

quotes.topic_title: Early build and launch: hand-rolled editor to VS Code
quotes.text: It was after maybe five weeks that we were living on the editor full-time, and had thrown away our previous editor, and we're using a new one.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A concrete dogfooding bar: switch your own workflow to the product quickly to validate usefulness.

quotes.topic_title: Early build and launch: hand-rolled editor to VS Code
quotes.text: And then we launched it out to the world within a couple of months from the first line of code, I think it was probably three months.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A specific speed benchmark for getting to public launch that teams can use as a forcing function.

quotes.topic_title: Early build and launch: hand-rolled editor to VS Code
quotes.text: And it was definitely a, "Let's just get this out to people and build in public quickly."
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A methodology for rapid iteration: ship early and let real users steer the roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: Early build and launch: hand-rolled editor to VS Code
quotes.text: That's actually why we switched to being based off of VS Code instead of just this hand-rolled thing. A lot of that was motivated by the initial user feedback, and then had been iterating in public from there.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product lesson: early feedback can justify abandoning bespoke infrastructure for a proven base to move faster.

quotes.topic_title: Growth dynamics: exponential, product-led, and focus
quotes.text: The three-month version wasn't very good, and so I think it's been a sustained paranoia about, there are all of these ways in which this thing could get better.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A repeatable mindset for product-led growth: assume the early product is inadequate and build a culture of continuous improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Growth dynamics: exponential, product-led, and focus
quotes.text: I think one of the things that has been most surprising too is that the growth has been fairly just consistent on an exponential, of just consistent month-over-month growth, accelerated at times by launches on our part and other things. But an exponential to begin with feels fairly slow and the numbers are really low, and so it didn't really feel off to the races to begin with.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A counterintuitive growth mental model: early exponential growth can feel slow, so teams should calibrate expectations and stay the course.

quotes.topic_title: Growth dynamics: exponential, product-led, and focus
quotes.text: It being essentially all just us, the team working on the product, and making the product good in lieu of other things one could spend one's time on.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A prioritization heuristic: bias time toward product quality over other early-company activities when product-led growth is plausible.

quotes.topic_title: Growth dynamics: exponential, product-led, and focus
quotes.text: But some of the normal things that people would maybe reach for in building the company early on, we really let those fires burn for a long time, especially when it came to things like sales and marketing.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Challenges conventional startup playbooks by explicitly deprioritizing sales/marketing to concentrate on product improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Growth dynamics: exponential, product-led, and focus
quotes.text: I think focus, and strategically picking the right things to build, and prioritizing effectively is tricky.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A concise reminder that the core execution challenge is not effort but choosing the right bets amid many plausible directions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We saw so many customers coming to us with teams of data engineers that struggled with the manual work required to clean messy spreadsheets.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Highlights a common, costly bottleneck (even for well-resourced teams) that practitioners can target for automation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: FileFeeds 2.0 allows non-technical teams to automate the process of transforming CSV and Excel files with just a simple prompt.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Actionable takeaway: shift data intake/transformation work left to non-technical teams using prompt-driven tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We've heard so many horror stories of outages from even just a single bad record, in transactions, employee files, purchase orders, you name it.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Concrete example of how small data-quality issues can cascade into major operational failures, motivating stronger validation gates.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Debugging these issues is often like finding a needle in a haystack.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for why reactive debugging doesn’t scale and why prevention/validation is higher leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: OneSchema stops any bad data from entering your system, and automatically validates your files, generating error reports with the exact issues in all bad files.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: implement a pre-ingestion validation layer with precise error reporting to prevent downstream incidents.

quotes.topic_title: Counterintuitive lesson: custom model development is essential
quotes.text: we definitely didn't expect to be doing any of our own model development when we started.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive shift: even teams that start as “model users” may end up needing in-house model work to win on product quality.

quotes.topic_title: Counterintuitive lesson: custom model development is essential
quotes.text: And at this point, every magic moment in Cursor involves a custom model in some way.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A concrete product strategy claim: the best user experiences (“magic moments”) can require targeted custom models rather than only relying on frontier APIs.

quotes.topic_title: Counterintuitive lesson: custom model development is essential
quotes.text: And one of the helpful things in doing this sort of model development is picking your spots carefully, not trying to reinvent the wheel, not trying to focus on places, and maybe where the best foundation models are excellent, but instead kind of focusing on their weaknesses, and how you can complement them.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Provides an actionable methodology for teams: selectively build custom models only where foundation models are weak, and use them as complements.

quotes.topic_title: Cursor’s model stack: autocomplete, retrieval, and diff filling
quotes.text: The places where we use our own models, so sometimes it's to survey a use case that a foundation model wouldn't be able to serve at all for cost or speed reasons.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A practical decision rule for when to build custom models: only where frontier models fail on cost/speed constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Cursor’s model stack: autocomplete, retrieval, and diff filling
quotes.text: But in code sometimes, when you edit a part of a code base, you're going to need to change things, and in other parts of code base, and it's entirely clear how you're going to need to change things.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation explaining why code autocomplete can be far more powerful than writing autocomplete.

quotes.topic_title: Cursor’s model stack: autocomplete, retrieval, and diff filling
quotes.text: those models need to be really fast, they need to give you a completion within 300 milliseconds.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A concrete performance target practitioners can use when designing interactive autocomplete experiences.

quotes.topic_title: Cursor’s model stack: autocomplete, retrieval, and diff filling
quotes.text: And then on the output side of things, we take the sketches of the changes that these models are suggesting, you make with that code base. And then we have models that then fill in the details of, the high level thinking is done by the smartest models, they spend a few tokens on doing that, and then these smaller specialty incredibly fast models, coupled with some inference tricks, then take those high level changes and turn them actually into full code diffs.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: An “ensemble” workflow: use frontier models for planning, then specialized small models to reliably and quickly generate concrete diffs.

quotes.topic_title: Cursor’s model stack: autocomplete, retrieval, and diff filling
quotes.text: You can kind of think about this as a mini Google search that's specifically built for finding the relevant parts of the code base to show one of these big models.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for retrieval: treat it as purpose-built search that selects context for large models.

quotes.topic_title: Defensibility and moats: keep building the best product
quotes.text: And I truly just think that the ceiling is so high that no matter what entrenchment you build, you can be leapfrogged.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that in fast-moving AI markets, classic lock-in is fragile and sustained product velocity matters more.

quotes.topic_title: Defensibility and moats: keep building the best product
quotes.text: I think one that comes to mind is the market for search engines at the end of 1999, or at the end of the '90s and beginning of the 2000s.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Offers a concrete analogy for thinking about AI defensibility as a “keep getting better” race rather than enterprise-style lock-in.

quotes.topic_title: Defensibility and moats: keep building the best product
quotes.text: You could keep getting value for the incremental hour of a smart person's time, the incremental R&D dollar for a really long time, you wouldn't run out of useful things to build.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for assessing whether a category supports durable advantage via sustained R&D compounding.

quotes.topic_title: Defensibility and moats: keep building the best product
quotes.text: But if you're in a place where big investments, and having more and more great people working on the right path can keep giving you value, then you can get these economies of scale of R&D, and you can deeply work on the technology in the right direction, and get to a place where that is defensible.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Defines a defensibility model for AI: scale R&D effectively and compound improvements to stay ahead.

quotes.topic_title: Defensibility and moats: keep building the best product
quotes.text: I really think it's just about building the best thing possible.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A simple, actionable north star for teams competing in markets where leapfrogs are always possible.

quotes.topic_title: Market structure: one general winner plus niches
quotes.text: And I think that the thing that people missed was that there was only so much you could do building an editor in the 2010s for coders, and the company that made money off of editors was doing things like making it easy to navigate around a code base, and doing some error checking and type checking for things, and having good debugging tools.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Reframes why historical IDE market fragmentation may not predict the AI tooling market: the old product surface area was inherently limited.

quotes.topic_title: Market structure: one general winner plus niches
quotes.text: The problem in front of all of us is the automation of a lot of busy work and knowledge work, and really changing all the areas of knowledge work in front of us to be much higher level and more productive.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A clear north-star framing for builders: focus on automating knowledge work to move users to higher-level, more productive workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Market structure: one general winner plus niches
quotes.text: I think it's much bigger than people have realized than the other building tools for developers in the past.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A market-sizing claim practitioners can use to justify bolder product scope and expectations than traditional devtools.

quotes.topic_title: Market structure: one general winner plus niches
quotes.text: I do think that there will be one company that builds the general tool that builds almost all the world's software, and that will be a very, very generationally big business.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Provides a market-structure thesis (winner-take-most general platform) that informs strategy: compete for the platform or own a niche.

quotes.topic_title: Market structure: one general winner plus niches
quotes.text: But I think that there will be kind of niches you can occupy in doing something for a particular segment of the market, or for a very particular part of the software development life cycle.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Actionable positioning advice: if you’re not the general platform, win by specializing in a segment or SDLC slice.

quotes.topic_title: Why Microsoft Copilot hasn’t dominated
quotes.text: I think that this is a market that's not super friendly to incumbents, in that a market that's friendly to incumbents might be one where there's only so much to do, it kind of gets commoditized fairly quickly, and you can bundle that in with other products, and where the ROI between different products is quite small.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A clear framework for when incumbents win: commoditization, bundling advantages, and low ROI differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Why Microsoft Copilot hasn’t dominated
quotes.text: And in that case, perhaps it doesn't make sense to buy the innovative solution, it makes sense to just kind of buy the thing that's bundled in with other stuff.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Counterintuitive buying behavior: even if a better product exists, bundling can dominate when differentiation is small.

quotes.topic_title: Why Microsoft Copilot hasn’t dominated
quotes.text: Another market that might be particularly helpful for incumbents is one where there's... From the get-go, you have your stuff in one place, and it's really, really excruciatingly hard to switch, and for better or for worse.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A second incumbent-advantage model: high switching costs and lock-in, independent of product innovation.

quotes.topic_title: Why Microsoft Copilot hasn’t dominated
quotes.text: I think in our case, you can try out different tools, and you can decide which product you think is better. And so that's not super friendly to incumbents, and that's more friendly to whoever you think is going to have the most innovative product.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Explains why fast-moving challengers can win in low-switching-cost markets where users can easily compare tools.

quotes.topic_title: Why Microsoft Copilot hasn’t dominated
quotes.text: I think it's been a little hard to coordinate among all the different departments and parties that might be involved in making something like this.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A practical execution insight: coordination complexity inside large orgs can slow iteration even with strong distribution.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding question: tips for new Cursor users (cut off)
quotes.text: a lot of being successful with Cursor is kind of having a taste for what the models can do, both what complexity of a task they can handle, and how much you need to specify things to that model, but having a taste for the quality of the model, and where its gaps exist, and what it can do and what it can't.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: A practical mental model: effective use comes from calibrating task complexity and prompt specificity to the model’s real capabilities and limits.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding question: tips for new Cursor users (cut off)
quotes.text: And right now, we don't do a good job in the product of educating people around that, and maybe giving people some swim lanes, giving people some guidelines.
quotes.speaker: Michael Truell
quotes.context: Highlights that onboarding should teach capability boundaries (“swim lanes”) rather than just features, to help users succeed faster.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding question: tips for new Cursor users (cut off)
quotes.text: if you could sit next to every new user that uses Cursor for the first time, just whisper a couple tips in their ear to be more successful, most successful with Cursor, what would be 1 or 2 tips?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames the onboarding challenge as delivering a small set of high-leverage behaviors that materially improve first-time outcomes.
